Category Archives: Tools

Project Management, Tools

How to organize your projects and life!

23/05/2014 Chris Lannister Leave a comment

There’s a lot of great free & paid tools out there that can help organise our work and our life! Here’s my list of personal and work related tools.

Trello

Trello is probably the best free project management app out there at the moment. Collaboration and revision history is fantastic and also includes clear privacy settings if you don’t wish to share your boards outside of your organisation.  I’ve made a list of some of the major benefits of this web application:

  • Easy collaboration
  • Activity history
  • Commenting on projects helps projects evolve efficiently
  • Check lists
  • Labelling
  • Assign members tasks
  • Set up due dates
  • Shared calender

In Trello, Boards can contain different categories and sub divisions to organise your project.

iCloud – Reminders, Notes & Calendar

The great thing about iCloud is that you don’t even need to own an apple device to take advantage of this cloud based solution. You’ll obviously need to access the site via a browser to access your information but I find the experience to satisfy personal needs in terms of organisation.  If you do have an apple phone, the convenience of quickly tapping away your thoughts and being able to easily access them later is great! Also if anyone wants to recommend any more anime, that would be great.

Google Docs

I absolutely love Google docs for many reasons:

  • It’s free
  • 15gb of free storage
  • Word/Excel/Power Point equivalents work well
  • Sharing and collaboration
  • Revision history for documents
  • “Connect More Apps”- A mini store of free &amp paid apps really add diversity to Drive
  • Create a website with Edit-ey!

Some of the pros mentioned above stray from the topic of project management but really need to be stated to fully understand how awesome this tool is. Collaboration is a major part of why you should be using Google Drive. Business price options are also not too expensive if you have a large team but small teams should be able to get away with using the free version.

Google Tasks


For all those who don’t fancy Apple, Google mail has a pretty good task manager built into it. Simply press Shift + T to bring up the tasks bar. This feature lacks in comparison to some of the other tools on this list but might suit some peoples requirements, it’s also super simple.

Base Camp

Although I generally only like to use free tools for my scale of project management, Basecamp definitely is worthy of a mention simply because of how good it is. They currently offer a 60 day trial so you can see if you like it or not. An awful lot of digital media companies use Basecamp and is regarded as one of the biggest players on the market. If you do own your own business with 5 or more employees then this is defiantly the tool you should be looking at.


A major advantage of Basecamp to the majority of the other tools is that the mobile app is very good. Purpose built for the smaller screen sizes, it breaks the projects down into more manageable chunks.

The people at Basecamp have put together very useful guides on how to use it here. This will also help you fully understand the functionality.

Conclusion

From this list, I cannot recommend Trello enough. It’s one of the best free project management tools out there. I’ll admit that Base Camp does 1 up Trello on a number of points but remember that it’s free! Please note that these tools will only help you if you fully embrace them. Make sure to get into the habit of using them and you’ll be rewarded with a sense of satisfaction with your organisation, very important if your working as a team.
